Author: kpro1982
Content: While you are correct that int means integer, it does not mean "single".  Instead,  `integer` and`double` are what's called `primative types`. A type is a container for data. Different types can hold different things.  A string type variable contains...well...a string.  A float contains a decimal number within a certain range. An int is a primative type that can contain a __whole number__ from −2,147,483,648 to +2,147,483,647. I'm not sure that enforce even has a double primitive type but generally a double can contain a much larger range of values by virtue of the fact that more memory is allocated to it.  I would recommend that you review the enforce syntax page which will give you some basic background. <https://community.bistudio.com/wiki/DayZ:Enforce_Script_Syntax>

This is just a simple example to demonstrate how to use the L3DT API to access and modify layers in a map based on a texture layer.

@echo off

:loop

tasklist /FI "IMAGENAME eq program_name.exe" 2>NUL | find /I /N "program_name.exe">NUL || goto program_not_running
ping -n 1 www.google.com >NUL || goto program_not_connected

:program_connected
REM Check if the program is responsive and not responding
wmic process where "name='program_name.exe'" call create
if %ERRORLEVEL%==1 goto program_not_responding

:program_not_responding
REM The program is not responding
taskkill /F /IM "program_name.exe"

REM Wait for 4 hours before starting the next iteration of the loop
timeout /T 14400 /NOBREAK >NUL

:wait_for_timeout
REM Check if the timeout has finished
timeout /T 1 /NOBREAK >NUL && goto loop
timeout /T 1 /NOBREAK >NUL || goto wait_for_timeout

:program_not_running
REM The program is not running

:program_not_connected
REM The program does not have network connectivity
```
